column4: Did you read the part down the page about the 'fstab'. That's what you want.
Is this in regards to your external usb ntfs drive?
yes
I just want it auto mounted with the ntfs3g driver instead of the standard ntfs driver. (so i can have write support)
Re-read the page http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=217009/ If you want it to automount you will need to change the line in your /etc/fstab file.
uhm, I asked this a few minutes ago, there is no entry for it in fstab, is there another file that deals with usb drives or do I have to make a new entry in fstab
New entry. Have you installed the ntfs-3g package etc. Where are you up to.
Have you figured out how to tell what device name your usb drive is?
It already automounts with the standard ntfs driver. I know its name, its mount point everything
all i want is the file that mounts it so I can tell it to mount with the ntfs3g driver instead of the standard ntfs driver
can you post the line from running the command 'mount' that lists the device and where it mounts to please?
the full line please.
/dev/sdc1 on /media/External type ntfs (rw,nosuid,nodev,uid=1000,gid=1000,umask=077,iocharset=utf8)
Did you not see this line on that website page: /dev/<your partition>     /media/<mount point>     ntfs-3g     defaults,locale=en_US.utf8   0    0
What file tells the system to mount the usb drive
You can probably add 'auto' to the options line: auto,defaults,locale=en_US.utf8
/etc/fstab
I saw the line, but fstab is not the file that mounts that drive. There is no mention of sdc1 in fstab
And i don't know what would happen if my computer tried to mount the same drive twice, Which driver would get used
Have a look at this page: http://danielnouri.org/blog/linux/persistent-usb-disk-naming-in-ubuntu.html?showcomments=yes
Probably Gnome Disk Mounter is doing something wacky. (I don't use the gui stuff)
